title: Baroness Hale's advice to young women is 'don't let the b*****ds get you down'
text:
Baroness Hale has given her number one piece of advice to young women in Britain, telling state school girls: 'Don't let the b*****ds get you down.'

The Supreme Court president gave a speech during a leadership conference at the Association of State Girls' Schools this morning.

She opened her talk by declaring 'let's hear it for the girly swots', causing a ripple of cheers and laughter from those in the audience.

The 74-year-old became a social media sensation after delivering the Supreme Court's judgement over Boris Johnson's proroguing of Parliament.

She donned a now iconic spider brooch as she read out the statement, declaring that the 11 judges unanimously agreed the suspension was 'unlawful'.

The Supreme Court president gave a speech during a leadership conference at the Association of State Girls' Schools this morning (pictured)

During today's speech, she recalled her time studying at Girton College, Cambridge that girls' voices could be crowded out by their louder male counterparts.

She also spoke about her father, who was the headmaster of a boys' grammar school, repeating his belief that 'single sex education should be compulsory for girls and banned for boys.'

Baroness Hale, who attended the college in the 60s, was one of only six women in her class of 116, from which she graduated with a starred first and top of the class.

She is currently the president of Supreme Court, a position she will stand down from in January when she is replaced by deputy president Lord Reed.

Lady Hale has previously been dubbed her 'the Beyonce of the legal world' and Britain's answer to the American Supreme Court justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.

The British judge has become known on the circuit for wearing oversized insect and animal brooches - choosing a spider for last month's major judgement.

Dozens took to Twitter to praise the gem-encrusted spider brooch - while others posted snaps of other pieces in the judge's collection. Highlights include a caterpillar (left) and a frog, as seen right during an appearance at the Supreme Court in October 2017

Lady Hale (pictured above) as she delivers the supreme court ruling that Boris Johnson's advice to the Queen to suspend Parliament for five weeks was unlawful

The unprecedented judgment was welcomed as 'a huge victory for the rule of law' by those challenging Mr Johnson's decision.

But it also led to criticism from Government members and pro-Brexit politicians and commentators.

The Supreme Court's inception ten years ago was a landmark legal development, separating the legislature from the judiciary as part of the then Labour government's constitutional reforms.

It is the final court of appeal for the UK, apart from Scottish criminal cases, and concentrates on issues of the greatest public and constitutional importance.

The Supreme Court has delivered a number of other significant rulings, including on assisted dying, abortion rights in Northern Ireland and the law on joint enterprise in criminal trials.
